feed.title: Interview: Elizabeth Banks Gets Serious
feed.subtitle: The actress takes a break from comedy for roles in Man on a Ledge and The Hunger Games.

link.title: Hunger Games Trailer Premieres

content.div:
LOS ANGELES - Sometimes, even Elizabeth Banks has to chase a movie role - specifically, one in the much-anticipated The Hunger Games, based on Suzanne Collins' popular young-adult novel (opening March 23).

But first, there was her cop role opposite Sam Worthington in the crime thriller, Man on a Ledge, which opens Jan. 27. "It was a gift for me," said Banks at a Beverly Hills hotel recently.

In the movie by first-time director Asger Leth, Banks is Lydia Anderson, a New York cop and suicide negotiator, trying to cope with a jumper by the name of Nick Cassidy (Worthington).

Cassidy is an escaped convict, and former New York cop, desperately trying to prove his innocence after being framed for a diamond heist.

The interplay between Banks' Lydia and Worthington's Nick provides a great deal of the dramatic tension, especially when the cop joins the escapee on the ledge.

And yes, that is Banks with Worthington, 21 floors up, trying not to shiver in the sequences, safety harnesses and all. "It was a little unnerving, occasionally," she said. But after a few weeks of shooting, she started getting into it. "I was looking forward to it. It was a real rush."

Banks also immersed herself in her character's world-weary posturing and depression, after failing to save a jumper on a previous assignment.

"That's the great thing about her," said Banks of Lydia. "She can't get her own life together, let alone try to save someone else's life. But, as Nick tries to redeem himself, so does Lydia."

Granted, the role is a change of pace for the actress known for comedic performances, including her breakout role as the wisecracking secretary, Miss Brant, in the Spider-Man movies.

Certainly, her character, Effie Trinket, in The Hunger Games, is a great deal more flamboyant.

"I was a very early adopter of The Hunger Games," she said of the popular three-novel series. "I read all the books, long before they were bestsellers."

Indeed, the actress has been tracking the The Hunger Games' movie adaptation since 2008. When director Gary Ross was hired to do the first movie, Banks was thrilled. She had played the loyal wife in his 2003 movie, Seabiscuit, and continued to be on good terms with him.

"So Gary brought me into his office," she recalled, "and we had a long conversation, at the end of which I was thinking, 'If he doesn't say I'm playing Effie, I'm gonna punch him in the face.'"

No punches were exchanged, and she was hired.

In the post-apocalyptic sci-fi film, Bank's Effie plays the escort for Katniss Everdeen (Jennifer Lawrence), who has volunteered to replace her younger sister in a fight-to-the-death match on live TV.

The first of three films is a high-concept, special-effects extravaganza for fans of all ages. In fact, The Hunger Games series is expected to supplant the Twilight franchise after Breaking Dawn - Part 2 is released in November.

"And I'm really pleased with my interpretation of Effie," added Banks. "I really feel like she's what I imagined when I read the books, so I'm pretty excited."

Mind you, it was a collaborative effort. "Everyone involved is Academy Award-nominated, from Gary Ross to the hair and makeup team, to the costume designer."

More critical for Banks is that Hunger Games author Collins approved of the casting, and early previews of scenes from the movie.

"That was the best thing about making The Hunger Games," Banks said. "Suzanne Collins sort of blessed the whole process. When people are like, 'How are you handling the pressure?' I'm like, 'There is no pressure, because Suzanne is happy.'"

Meanwhile, Banks is waiting for a call from 30 Rock's Tina Fey, about her Emmy-nominated recurring role as TV anchorwoman, Avery Jessup-Donaghy, who is married to Jack Donaghy (Alec Baldwin) on the show. As part a subplot in Season 5, Avery is held captive in North Korea, then forced to marry the son of Kim Jong-iI, Kim Jong-un.

With the death of the real North Korean dictator on Dec. 18, Banks said the Emmy-winning sitcom will likely take advantage of the situation. She's just not sure how, since 30 Rock started Season 6 on Jan. 12.

"But there will be a resolution," Banks predicted.

entry.title: Top 10 Heist Movies

link.Abstract: The characters in these suspenseful flicks have stolen gold, jewels and money -- and our hearts.
link.title: [ more ]

link.Abstract:
It's difficult, if not impossible, to resist a movie featuring charismatic people stealing stuff. In Man on a Ledge, Sam Worthington's character creates the ultimate distraction on a Manhattan hotel rooftop while his cohorts attempt the biggest diamond heist ever committed, all in an attempt to prove his innocence.
But successful heist movies don't necessarily need a plot based on revenge and justice, and we've put together the Top 10 Heist Movies to prove it. The characters in these suspenseful flicks have stolen gold, jewels and money, but they've also stolen the most valuable thing of all: our hearts.
--Dose.ca
link.title: In Man on a Ledge, Sam Worthington's character creates the ultimate distraction on a Manhattan hotel rooftop while his cohorts attempt the biggest diamond heist ever committed, all in an attempt to prove his innocence.

link.Abstract: Tower Heist isn't the first time we've seen movie characters who just aren't suited to a life of crime. Check out 10 more clumsy movie crooks.
link.title: Top 10 Clumsy Crooks

link.title: Taylor Swift attends the annual Nashville Symphony Ball at the Schermerhorn Symphony Center on December 10, 2011 in Nashville, Tennessee.

link.Abstract: Watch Taylor Swift's new video for "Ours," wherein everyone's favourite country-pop star plays an office drone. The work world, much like any Swift video, is a lot like high school.
link.title: Zach Gilford, Cat Videos Help Taylor Swift Make it Through the Work Day; She's Just Like Us!

link.Abstract: Taylor Swift's Speak Now World Tour is at its end. The country-pop star gave the first of two sold-out shows at New York's Madison Square Garden Nov. 21. We've got photos.
link.title: Photos: Taylor Swift at Madison Square Garden

link.Abstract: Taylor Swift always looks surprised in photos. But here's some news that really deserves an OMG-face: Swift was forced to cancel a series of concert dates due to bronchitis. Yikes! Get well soon, Swifty. It's time you built up your strength. Here, have a sandwich. In fact, have 10. We hope Swift's feeling better in time for her July 14 show in Montreal.
link.title: Gallery: Eat a Sandwich, Taylor Swift

link.Abstract: Taylor Swift has many faces, but they all look surprised.
link.title: Photos: Taylor Swift Looking Surprised
